title: More pension savers denied new freedoms as ANOTHER insurer delays plans
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Sat, Sep 5, 2015, 11:12 BST - UK Markets closed More pension savers denied new freedoms as ANOTHER insurer delays plans By Katie Morley | Telegraph – 16 minutes ago 7.51 +0.75 
Aegon (Swiss: AGN.SW - news ) becomes the second insurance giant to shelve plans to let customers use the new pension freedoms 
Aegon, one of Britain's biggest pension firms, has shelved plans to offer savers "bank account" access to their pensions for at least a year, as ministers prepare to grill the industry over why the new freedoms are not working. 
The pension freedoms, announced in March 2014 and supposed to come into effect in April, were supposed to allow all over-55s access to their retirement funds. 
The Telegraph can disclose that Aegon, which has two million customers, has blocked savers from having flexible access to their retirement funds until April 2016, unless they agree to pay for expensive financial advice. 
Savers who cannot afford a financial adviser and want to retire now are instead being given three options: cash in the entire pension and face a tax bill, swap the whole fund for a lifetime annuity income, or undertake a potentially costly transfer to a rival company. 
On Monday the Government starts a formal process of collecting evidence about the problems facing savers who want access to their pension cash, first highlighted by this newspaper through our Make Pension Freedoms Work campaign. * Millions of savers hit as Friends Life (Other OTC: RSLLF - news ) performs U-turn on pension freedoms * Make pension freedoms work: our five demands 
Ros Altmann, the pensions minister, said: "People who really do need to take their money should not be denied the chance unfairly. The real problem is the difficulty and large cost they face if they transfer to another provider. 
"We are looking at this in our consultation and investigations and we want members of the public who are experiencing difficulties in this regard to let us know what is happening." 
In June Friends Life, part of Aviva (Other OTC: AIVAF - news ) , cancelled plans to offer savers the new flexibilities, sparking concerns among ministers that other firms could follow suit by delaying or refusing flexible access. 
This latest news cements those fears and increases the number of savers known to be currently facing barriers to using their pensions like bank accounts from five to seven million. 
Aegon’s decision to delay the freedoms for most people comes despite it having provided new flexible pensions to customers who are prepared to pay for a financial adviser from April. 
An Aegon spokesperson said: “Pensions can be complex and requires customers to make decisions about investments, how much income to take and how long their savings might need to last. We are still working through our offer and will launch when we are confident it will meet customer needs.” 
Have you been denied pension freedom? Email: katie.morley@telegraph.co.uk
